title: Graphs of kinetic energy as a function of time

content.description: An object of mass m is initially at rest and free to move without friction in any direction in the xy-plane. A constant net force of magnitude F directed in the +x direction acts on the object for 1 s. Immediately thereafter a constant net force of the same magnitude F directed in the +y direction acts on the object for 1 s. After this, no forces act on the object.
content.question: Which of the following graphs best represents the kinetic energy K of the object as a function of time?

choices.label: Choice A has a curve that goes from the origin to the point at the second y-axis tick mark and time 3 seconds. The curve is increasing and concave up.

Choice B starts at the origin and is increasing and concave up to the point at the first y-axis tick mark and time 1 second. It has a cusp at this point, and is increasing and concave up from here to the point at the second y-axis tick mark and 2 seconds. From here it is a horizontal line to time three seconds.

Choice C starts at the origin and is increasing and concave up to the first y-axis tick mark and time 1 second, and is then increasing and concave down to the second y-axis tick mark and time 2 seconds. From here it is a horizontal line to time 3 seconds.
Choice D starts at the origin and increases linearly to the second y-axis tick mark and 2 seconds. From here it is a horizontal line to time 3 seconds.

Choice E starts at time zero seconds at the first y-axis tick mark, and is horizontal until time 1 second. Then there is a vertical line to the point at the second y-axis tick mark and time 1 second. From here it is a horizontal line to time 3 seconds.

content.answer: Choice B starts at the origin and is increasing and concave up to the point at the first y-axis tick mark and time 1 second. It has a cusp at this point, and is increasing and concave up from here to the point at the second y-axis tick mark and 2 seconds. From here it is a horizontal line to time three seconds.

skill.text: 2.D: Predict new values or factors of change of physical quantities using functional dependence between variables.
